Under Review
======

[1] On the Mechanisms of Ability Peer Effects, with <a href="https://sites.google.com/view/nsalamanca/home" target="_blank">N. Salamanca</a>.
------

Description: We study the effects of higher-achieving peers on standardized test scores and several mechanisms, in a setting where students are randomly assigned to classrooms within schools.

Working Paper: 
* <a href="https://melbourneinstitute.unimelb.edu.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0005/3505685/wp2020n19.pdf" target="_blank">Melbourne Institute Working Paper No. 19/20 (October 2020)</a>
* <a href="http://ftp.iza.org/dp13938.pdf" target="_blank">IZA Discussion Paper No. 13938 (December 2020)</a>.

[2] Child Health and Parental Responses to an Unconditional Cash Transfer at Birth, with J. Lynch, A. Meunier, R. Pilkington, and <a href="http://www.stefanie-schurer.com" target="_blank">S. Schurer</a>.
------

Description: We estimate the effect of an unconditional cash transfer on early life health outcomes and health care utilization of children within their first year of life, using administrative data from South Australia.

Working paper coming soon.
